Forests

They develop in areas with temperate and cold climates.

The trees in the forests are arranged in a single layer and are very spaced apart, and they have a dormant period during the winter.

There is less variety of vegetables and animals than in the jungle.

In temperate zones, forests are made up of deciduous trees and shrubs, while those in colder regions consist of conifers, evergreen trees.

The wildlife of the forests is mainly made up of predators, such as foxes, wolves, cougars, and lynxes.

In temperate forests, deforestation for wood use or for the development of agriculture and livestock leads to the loss of animal and plant species.

The taiga is a forest characteristic of the cold climates of the northern hemisphere; it develops in Canada and Siberia.

The characteristic species are firs, pines, larches, and birches.

Its fauna is composed of animals that withstand the cold: moose, bison, wolves, bears, lynxes, squirrels, marmots, beavers, and deer; many of them hibernate.


Coniferous forest, Chile
